issue.title: `invalid_blocks` error when using type `rich_text`

labels.name: question
labels.description: M-T: User needs support to use the project

labels.name: pkg:web-api
labels.description: applies to `@slack/web-api`

issue.body:
#### Packages:

- [x] `@slack/web-api`

### Reproducible in:

#### The Slack SDK version
```
"slack/web-api": "^6.7.2",
"slack/logger": "^3.0.0",
"slack/types": "^2.7.0",
```

#### Node.js runtime version
```
v12.22.10
```
#### OS info

```
ProductName:	macOS
ProductVersion:	12.2.1
BuildVersion:	21D62
Darwin Kernel Version 21.3.0: Wed Jan  5 21:37:58 PST 2022; root:xnu-8019.80.24~20/RELEASE_X86_64
```

#### Steps to reproduce:
```
slackWebClient.chat.postMessage({
    channel: "ABC123",
    blocks: [{
        "type": "rich_text",
        "elements": [{
            "type": "rich_text_list",
            "elements": [{
                    "type": "rich_text_section",
                    "elements": [{
                        "type": "text",
                        "text": "First"
                    }]
                },
                {
                    "type": "rich_text_section",
                    "elements": [{
                        "type": "text",
                        "text": "Second"
                    }]
                }
            ],
            "style": "bullet",
            "indent": 0
        }]
    }],
});
```

### Expected result:

I would expect this to work since in the [Slack Block Kit Builder](https://app.slack.com/block-kit-builder/) it seems a legit block

### Actual result:

```
Error: An API error occurred: invalid_blocks
```

comment.body:
@vvo Great question! Almost a month ago, the platform unlocked the feature to 3rd party apps, so as you've noticed, you can now use rich_text blocks in a message and modal inputs!

See also:
* https://github.com/slackapi/java-slack-sdk/pull/1215
* https://github.com/slackapi/python-slack-sdk/pull/1406
* https://github.com/slackapi/bolt-js/pull/1963
* https://github.com/slackapi/node-slack-sdk/pull/1643

commits.message: Split out team.* API arguments into own file. Document team.* API methods.
Split out usergroups.* API arguments into own file. Document usergroups.* API methods.
Document and deprecate workflows.* API methods.
Describe `users.*` API calls with JSDoc. Document cursor pagination properties. Document users.* API arguments.

issue.title: replace axios with fetch

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: M-T: A feature request for new functionality

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: M-T: An issue where more input is needed to reach a decision

labels.name: pkg:web-api
labels.description: applies to `@slack/web-api`

issue.body:
(Describe your issue and goal here) 

#### Packages:

Select all that apply:

- [x] `@slack/web-api`
- [ ] `@slack/rtm-api`
- [ ] `@slack/webhooks`
- [ ] `@slack/oauth`
- [ ] `@slack/socket-mode`
- [ ] `@slack/types`
- [ ] I don't know

### Requirements

could you replace axios with fetch instead? 

And preferable don't depend on any FormData, Blob, XHR, fetch dependency? let users bring there own instances instead b/c they exist globally in NodeJS now and if they need they can polyfill this stuff by themself. using undici, node-fetch or anything else

comment.body:
Worth revisiting this issue as I am inching towards a new major release of web-api (with things like [better type safety of API arguments](https://github.com/slackapi/node-slack-sdk/pull/1673)). In the next release, web-api will require node v18 minimum.

I wonder if in node 18+ it is easier to implement some of the more corporate-y features web-api provides like proxies.

comment.body:
And security 🧐

Snyk just posted [this CSRF issue](https://security.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-AXIOS-6032459) with Axios.

issue.title: @slack/socket-mode - Handle event.type === disconnect && reason === 'too_many_websockets'

labels.name: needs info
labels.description: An issue that is claimed to be a bug and hasn't been reproduced, or otherwise needs more info

labels.name: pkg:socket-mode
labels.description: applies to `@slack/socket-mode`

issue.body:
👋  from Slack Customer Success. 

Current state of @slack/socket-mode package does not account for `event.type === disconnect && reason === 'too_many_websockets'`, causing unhandled error to bubble up when Slack decides to disconnect existing connection during `connecting:handshaking` state

Here's a log output - the reconnect happens initially after the app receives `event.type === 'disconnect' && reason === 'warning'`

#### Packages:

Select all that apply:

- [ ] `@slack/web-api`
- [ ] `@slack/rtm-api`
- [ ] `@slack/webhooks`
- [ ] `@slack/oauth`
- [x] `@slack/socket-mode`
- [ ] `@slack/types`
- [ ] I don't know

### Requirements

Feature request: have the app catch `reason === 'too_many_websockets'`

Please read the [Contributing guidelines](https://github.com/slackapi/node-slack-sdk/blob/main/.github/contributing.md) and [Code of Conduct](https://slackhq.github.io/code-of-conduct) before creating this issue or pull request. By submitting, you are agreeing to those rules.

comment.body:
I've posted your issue to the java-slack-sdk repo: https://github.com/slackapi/java-slack-sdk/issues/1223

Best to follow that issue along since the code for the node socket-mode library is different from the java bits.

issue.title: `WebClient.chat.postMessage` throwing `fatal_error` intermittently
issue.body:
#### Packages:

Select all that apply:

- [x] `@slack/web-api`
- [ ] `@slack/rtm-api`
- [ ] `@slack/webhooks`
- [ ] `@slack/oauth`
- [ ] `@slack/socket-mode`
- [ ] `@slack/types`
- [ ] I don't know

### Reproducible in:

#### The Slack SDK version

```bash
"slack/socket-mode": "^1.3.2",
"slack/web-api": "^6.9.0",
```

#### Node.js runtime version

v16.20.0

#### OS info

Ubuntu

#### Steps to reproduce:

This is an intermittent issue, but the steps before occurring are:
1. Initialize a `@slack/web-api` `WebClient`
2. Call `chat.postMessage()` with some arguments, to a valid channel (i.e. a call that would otherwise work)

### Expected result:

Not to throw a `fatal_error`, and succeed in posting slack message.

### Actual result:

Posting the message fails, and throws (probably rejects) with error:

```
      "type": "Error",
      "message": "An API error occurred: fatal_error",
      "stack":
          Error: An API error occurred: fatal_error
              at platformErrorFromResult (/usr/src/app/node_modules/@slack/web-api/dist/errors.js:56:33)
              at WebClient.apiCall (/usr/src/app/node_modules/@slack/web-api/dist/WebClient.js:181:56)
              at runMicrotasks (<anonymous>)
              at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:95:5)
              [omitted]
      "code": "slack_webapi_platform_error",
      "data": {
        "ok": false,
        "error": "fatal_error",
        "response_metadata": {}
      }
```

This occurred several times around 12pm - 12:30pm EDT on 18/10/2023. There are no slack outages reported during this time frame, therefore I am assuming this to be a client failure.

### Requirements

For general questions/issues about Slack API platform or its server-side, could you submit questions at https://my.slack.com/help/requests/new instead. :bow:

Please read the [Contributing guidelines](https://github.com/slackapi/node-slack-sdk/blob/main/.github/contributing.md) and [Code of Conduct](https://slackhq.github.io/code-of-conduct) before creating this issue or pull request. By submitting, you are agreeing to those rules.

comment.body: Noticing some further intermittent issues for the same API today around 11:00AM EDT (`fatal_error`). Is there another such known issue/outage?

commits.message: do not apply naming convention linter rules to imports; those might come from external dependencies.
remove tests related to cursorPagination warning, which was removed.
Move request arguments for users.* apis to own file. Removed the warning around using cursor pagination `paginate()`

comment.body: I see, that makes sense! Maintainers of this project should follow the same approach. I will do my best to document the fields in a nice way as I work through this.

pull_request.title: Web API Type Safety
pull_request.body:
This work builds off #1670. Web API arguments and responses are type safe now, though responses were not closely validated as that would require a lot more work. I am also leaving notes on API arguments and responses as I test them out, with breadcrumbs on future improvements / breaking changes.

Once merged, this PR intends to fix #1323.

# Feedback Requested

1. Mainly: the changes in `src/methods.ts`. Yes, it's a lot of changes, but let me know if you have questions. These changes came as a result of studying the API metadata schemas and descriptors from the backend code, together with reading the API reference docs.
2. For many of the methods, I didn't model many of their either/or constraints (e.g. provide either a `trigger_id` or an `interactivity_pointer`) as that would take a lot more work. However, if you think it's worthwhile, let me know and I can tackle it, though it will likely delay this PR further.
3. Similarly, I could JSDoc all the things to really take this to the next level.
4. Long-term, I think we should keep the API argument and response shapes in the `@slack/types` package. Thoughts? 👍  / 👎 ?

Tackling 2-4 above could also be done in a later PR and released as another major revision.

# Deprecations being removed

While here, and since this PR is in prep for a new major release, also took the opportunity to remove methods that were marked as deprecated:

- [x] `channels.*`
- [x] `groups.*`
- [x] `im.*`
- [x] `mpim.*`

# ❓ New Deprecations

Should we deprecate the following method groups, given they are mentioned as such in their reference docs?

- `oauth.access` (superseded by the new `oauth.v2.*` methods)
- `stars.*` (docs specifically mention end-users cant interact with them in the client anymore, presumably will be replaced with the Later feature at some point)
- `workflows.*` (legacy steps-from-apps related workflow methods)

pull_request.title: Web API Type Safety
pull_request.body:
This work builds off #1670. Web API arguments and responses are type safe now, though responses were not closely validated as that would require a lot more work. I am also leaving notes on API arguments and responses as I test them out, with breadcrumbs on future improvements / breaking changes.

Once merged, this PR intends to fix #1323.

# Feedback Requested

1. Mainly: the changes in `src/methods.ts`. Yes, it's a lot of changes, but let me know if you have questions. These changes came as a result of studying the API metadata schemas and descriptors from the backend code, together with reading the API reference docs.
2. For many of the methods, I didn't model many of their either/or constraints (e.g. provide either a `trigger_id` or an `interactivity_pointer`) as that would take a lot more work. However, if you think it's worthwhile, let me know and I can tackle it, though it will likely delay this PR further.
3. Similarly, I could JSDoc all the things to really take this to the next level.
4. Long-term, I think we should keep the API argument and response shapes in the `@slack/types` package. Thoughts? 👍  / 👎 ?

Tackling 2-4 above could also be done in a later PR and released as another major revision.

# Deprecations being removed

While here, and since this PR is in prep for a new major release, also took the opportunity to remove methods that were marked as deprecated:

- [x] `channels.*`
- [x] `groups.*`
- [x] `im.*`
- [x] `mpim.*`

# ❓ New Deprecations

Should we deprecate the following method groups, given they are mentioned as such in their reference docs?

- `oauth.access` (superseded by the new `oauth.v2.*` methods)
- `stars.*` (docs specifically mention end-users cant interact with them in the client anymore, presumably will be replaced with the Later feature at some point)
- `workflows.*` (legacy steps-from-apps related workflow methods)

# Updates/Testing

I did my best to cross-reference [all the methods against the documentation](https://api.slack.com/methods):

- [x] `admin.*`
- [x] `api.test`
- [x] `apps.*`
- [x] `auth.*`
- [x] `bookmarks.*`
- [x] `calls.*`
- [x] `chat.*`
- [x] `conversations.*`
- [x] `dialog.open`
- [x] `dnd.*`
- [x] `emoji.list`
- [x] `files.*`
- [x] `migration.exchange`
- [x] `oauth.*`
- [x] `openid.*`
- [x] `pins.*`
- [x] `reactions.*`
- [x] `reminders.*`
- [x] `rtm.*`
- [x] `search.*`
- [x] `stars.*`
- [x] `team.*`
- [x] `usergroups.*`
- [x] `users.*`
- [x] `views.*`
- [x] `workflows.*`

comment.body: @filmaj Yes, they are. The benefits of the tests in the SDK is to detect unknown properties. When enabling [this detection mode](https://github.com/slackapi/java-slack-sdk/blob/v1.34.0/slack-api-client/src/test/java/config/SlackTestConfig.java#L81C16-L81C42), JSON parser throws an exeption with a newly added property information. The unit test results in a failure, and then we, developers, can modfiy the code until it passes the test without any exceptions.
